Operation 'LegalNotice' has semantic quality issues: vague_description, missing_context, missing_output_details. Original description is too brief and lacks context about the response format (gzip-compressed HTML), file type, and authentication requirements. Summary is generic. Enhanced version clarifies what the operation returns and its format, helping AI agents understand when to use this endpoint for license/legal information retrieval.

data.current_description: All licenses of programs used by Home.
data.summary_suggestion: Retrieve legal notice and license information
data.description_suggestion: Retrieves the compressed legal notice file containing all licenses and attributions for programs used by the Google Home device. Returns a gzip-compressed HTML document (NOTICE.html.gz) containing license information. This is a static file endpoint requiring no authentication.
data.reasoning: Original description is too brief and lacks context about the response format (gzip-compressed HTML), file type, and authentication requirements. Summary is generic. Enhanced version clarifies what the operation returns and its format, helping AI agents understand when to use this endpoint for license/legal information retrieval.

message: Operation 'ChromecastIcon' has semantic quality issues: vague_description, missing_context, not_actionable, missing_output_details. Original description is confusing with contradictory information (says 'no longer exists' but then describes a redirect). Lacks clarity on deprecation status and actionability. Enhanced version explicitly marks as deprecated, clarifies the non-functional state, explains historical behavior, and guides AI agents away from using this endpoint while providing context for legacy integrations.

data.current_description:
**Update:** This no longer exists. It's not useful, anyway.

 A redirect to `http://www.gstatic.com/eureka/images/eureka_device.png`
data.description_suggestion: Deprecated endpoint that previously served the Chromecast device icon. This endpoint no longer functions and should not be used. Historically, it redirected to the external Google Static CDN URL: http://www.gstatic.com/eureka/images/eureka_device.png. For current device icon resources, use alternative endpoints or access the external CDN URL directly.
data.reasoning: Original description is confusing with contradictory information (says 'no longer exists' but then describes a redirect). Lacks clarity on deprecation status and actionability. Enhanced version explicitly marks as deprecated, clarifies the non-functional state, explains historical behavior, and guides AI agents away from using this endpoint while providing context for legacy integrations.

message: Operation 'Scanfordevices' has semantic quality issues: vague_summary, vague_description, missing_output_details, poor_ai_interpretability. Original summary is too generic. Description references an external note that may not be accessible to AI agents. Added clarity about what devices are discovered, timeout behavior, how to retrieve results, and authentication requirement for better AI agent interpretability.

data.current_description:
*See note for Bluetooth under `/setup/bluetooth/status`*

This initiates scan for other bluetooth speakers/devices. Scan results will be updated continuously for `timeout` seconds.
To get the scan results, see /setup/bluetooth/scan_results.
data.description_suggestion: Initiates a Bluetooth scan to discover nearby Bluetooth speakers and devices. The scan runs for a specified timeout duration (in seconds) and continuously updates results. Scan results are cached and can be retrieved via GET /setup/bluetooth/scan_results. Requires local authorization token.
data.reasoning: Original summary is too generic. Description references an external note that may not be accessible to AI agents. Added clarity about what devices are discovered, timeout behavior, how to retrieve results, and authentication requirement for better AI agent interpretability.

Description relies on external reference and vague claim about 'self-descriptive' field names. Improved description specifies what information is returned and adds authentication context for AI agent clarity.

data.current_description:
*See note for Bluetooth under `/setup/bluetooth/status`*

This gives a list of all paired or 'bonded' devices. The response field names are self-descriptive.
data.description_suggestion: Retrieves a list of all Bluetooth devices that have been paired (bonded) with the Google Home device. Returns device information including device name, address, and connection status. Requires local authorization token.
data.reasoning: Summary is clear and actionable. Description relies on external reference and vague claim about 'self-descriptive' field names. Improved description specifies what information is returned and adds authentication context for AI agent clarity.

data.current_description: **Note:** Not sure how the password is encrypted. Might be using the public certificate from /setup/eureka_info. So this cannot be used as of now. If someone figures it out, please [create a new issue here](https://github.com/rithvikvibhu/GHLocalApi/issues/new).
data.description_suggestion: Connects the Google Home device to a specified Wi-Fi network. Requires SSID and password in the request body. Password encryption method is currently undocumented - this endpoint may not be functional. Requires local authorization token. See /setup/eureka_info for potential encryption details.
data.reasoning: Summary is clear but description is unhelpful for AI agents - it only states the endpoint doesn't work. Improved description explains the intended functionality, input requirements, current limitations, and references relevant endpoints for context.

message: Operation 'GetSavedNetworks' has semantic quality issues: missing_output_details, missing_context. Summary is clear. Description includes TODO comment and incomplete documentation about wpa_auth and wpa_cipher values. Improved description clarifies field purposes, explains how wpa_id is used with other endpoints, and adds authentication context for AI agent completeness.

data.current_description:
This gets a list of all saved Wi-Fi networks.

Each network has `ssid`, `wpa_auth`, `wpa_cipher` and `wpa_id`.
`wpa_id` is an incrementing number used to identify a saved network.
#TODO: Add values for `wpa_auth` and `wpa_cipher`.
data.description_suggestion: Retrieves a list of all Wi-Fi networks saved on the Google Home device. Each network entry includes: ssid (network name), wpa_id (unique identifier for the network), wpa_auth (authentication type), and wpa_cipher (encryption cipher). The wpa_id can be used with /setup/forget_wifi to remove networks. Requires local authorization token.
data.reasoning: Summary is clear. Description includes TODO comment and incomplete documentation about wpa_auth and wpa_cipher values. Improved description clarifies field purposes, explains how wpa_id is used with other endpoints, and adds authentication context for AI agent completeness.

message: Operation 'GetWi-FiScanResults' has semantic quality issues: missing_context, missing_output_details. Summary is clear. Description explains caching behavior but lacks details about what information is returned in each result. Improved description specifies typical response fields and adds authentication context for better AI agent understanding of response structure.

data.current_description:
This gets a list of all nearby Wi-Fi access points.

The list only has the connected AP by default. Once a scan is triggered by `/setup/scan_wifi`, the whole list is cached for ~3 minutes. Then it will revert to returning only the connected AP again.
data.description_suggestion: Retrieves a list of nearby Wi-Fi access points discovered by the Google Home device. By default, returns only the currently connected access point. After triggering a scan via POST /setup/scan_wifi, returns the full list of discovered networks cached for approximately 3 minutes before reverting to connected AP only. Each result includes SSID, signal strength, and security information. Requires local authorization token.
data.reasoning: Summary is clear. Description explains caching behavior but lacks details about what information is returned in each result. Improved description specifies typical response fields and adds authentication context for better AI agent understanding of response structure.

message: Operation 'Timezones' has semantic quality issues: vague_summary, vague_description, poor_ai_interpretability. Original summary is a noun, not action-oriented. Description lacks context about use cases and authentication requirements. Improved version clarifies the action (retrieve), purpose (timezone configuration), and authentication status for AI agent decision-making.

data.current_description: Simply returns a list of all supported timezones.
data.description_suggestion: Returns a list of all timezones supported by the Google Home device. This endpoint is useful for configuring device timezone settings or validating timezone values. No authentication required.
data.reasoning: Original summary is a noun, not action-oriented. Description lacks context about use cases and authentication requirements. Improved version clarifies the action (retrieve), purpose (timezone configuration), and authentication status for AI agent decision-making.

message: Operation 'AppDeviceID' has semantic quality issues: vague_summary, missing_output_details, unclear_purpose, poor_ai_interpretability. Original summary is a noun phrase. Description contains uncertainty ('Not sure what the other two are') and lacks clarity on purpose and return values. Improved version provides action-oriented summary, clarifies the mandatory app_id requirement, explains the purpose of returned values, and removes uncertainty for better AI agent interpretability.

data.current_description:
This gives "app device id", "certificate" and "signed data".
The `app_id` in the request is mandatory and refers to Chromecast backdrop/screensaver app. It has to be set to `E8C28D3C`.

The certificate is valid and issued by `Chromecast ICA 6 (Audio Assist), Google Inc`.

Not sure what the other two are.
data.description_suggestion: Generates device credentials for Chromecast backdrop/screensaver applications. Requires `app_id` parameter set to `E8C28D3C`. Returns an app device ID, X.509 certificate (issued by Chromecast ICA 6), and signed data for device authentication. The certificate and signed data are used for secure communication with Chromecast services.

message: Operation 'EurekaInfo' has semantic quality issues: vague_summary, missing_input_details, poor_ai_interpretability. Original summary is a noun phrase. Description is dense and unclear about parameter purposes. Improved version clarifies the action (retrieve), organizes parameter information logically, explains the purpose of each parameter, provides concrete examples, and specifies authentication status for better AI agent interpretability.

data.current_description:
This gives most of the device info. The GET parameter `param` is a comma separated list of json keys to fetch. Currently, these params are known: `version,audio,name,build_info,detail,device_info,net,wifi,setup,settings,opt_in,opencast,multizone,proxy,night_mode_params,user_eq,room_equalizer,sign,aogh,ultrasound,mesh`
 
Nested items can also be filtered using the dot notation. Example: `audio.digital`
 
The `options` GET parameter is always set to `detail` or `detail,sign`. `sign` signs the `nonce` and returns some value.

The `nonce` GET parameter is an integer value signed with needed (see `option` parameter above).
data.summary_suggestion: Retrieve device information with selective filtering
data.description_suggestion: Retrieves comprehensive device information from the Google Home device. Supports selective field retrieval via the `param` query parameter (comma-separated list of keys: version, audio, name, build_info, detail, device_info, net, wifi, setup, settings, opt_in, opencast, multizone, proxy, night_mode_params, user_eq, room_equalizer, sign, aogh, ultrasound, mesh). Supports nested field filtering using dot notation (e.g., `audio.digital`). The `options` parameter controls response format ('detail' or 'detail,sign'). The `nonce` parameter provides an integer value for cryptographic signing when 'sign' option is used. No authentication required.
data.reasoning: Original summary is a noun phrase. Description is dense and unclear about parameter purposes. Improved version clarifies the action (retrieve), organizes parameter information logically, explains the purpose of each parameter, provides concrete examples, and specifies authentication status for better AI agent interpretability.

message: Operation 'NightModesettings' has semantic quality issues: vague_summary, missing_input_details, missing_output_details. Original summary is too generic. Description is comprehensive but lacks structure and clarity on parameter types/ranges. Reorganized to clearly separate configuration options, added parameter value ranges, and clarified the relationship with eureka_info endpoint for better AI agent decision-making.

data.current_description:
This sets night mode options.  
To view currently set values, use /setup/eureka_info.  
If `enabled` is set to false, night mode is disabled and the other values do not matter.  
`led_brightness` and `volume` refer to the maximum LED Brightness and Volume that is set during night mode.  
 `demo_to_user` is always set to `true` so change in values will be visible in realtime (like brightness).  
`windows`: A combination of `length_hours` and `start_hour` is used to define start and end times for night mode. In this example, night mode starts at 10 PM (22) and ends at 6 AM (8 hours later). `windows.days` is an array of days of week when night mode will be enabled. Example: 0->Sunday, 1-> Monday, ..., 6->Saturday.
data.summary_suggestion: Configure night mode parameters and schedule
data.description_suggestion: Configures night mode settings including enabled state, maximum LED brightness, maximum volume, and schedule. Parameters: `enabled` (boolean) to enable/disable night mode; `led_brightness` and `volume` (0-1 range) set maximum levels during night mode; `windows` defines active periods with `start_hour` (0-23), `length_hours` duration, and `days` array (0=Sunday through 6=Saturday) for weekly schedule. Set `demo_to_user` to true for real-time preview of changes. Returns 200 OK. To view current settings, use GET /setup/eureka_info.
data.reasoning: Original summary is too generic. Description is comprehensive but lacks structure and clarity on parameter types/ranges. Reorganized to clearly separate configuration options, added parameter value ranges, and clarified the relationship with eureka_info endpoint for better AI agent decision-making.

message: Operation 'GetAlarmsandTimers' has semantic quality issues: vague_summary, missing_output_details. Summary is generic. Description is detailed but lacks clarity on response structure and return format. Reorganized to clearly separate alarm vs timer fields, clarified status values, and explicitly stated the return format for better AI agent understanding of response structure.

data.current_description:
This gives a list of all active alarms and timers.

Both alarms and timers have `id`s which can be used to delete them. (There is no known way of creating/deleting yet). The value of `status` have different meanings for alarms and timers (given below).

Alarms have `date_pattern` and `time_pattern` with day, month, year, hour, minute, second. `fire_time` is the same in unix time (milliseconds, not seconds).  
`status` is 1 for set up and 2 for ringing.
 
Timers have `original_duration` is the original duration.  
`status` is 1 for set up and 3 for ringing.
data.summary_suggestion: Retrieve all active alarms and timers
data.description_suggestion: Retrieves a list of all currently active alarms and timers on the device. Each alarm/timer includes an `id` that can be used with the delete endpoint. Response structure differs between alarms and timers: Alarms include `date_pattern` (day, month, year), `time_pattern` (hour, minute, second), `fire_time` (unix timestamp in milliseconds), and `status` (1=set up, 2=ringing). Timers include `original_duration`, and `status` (1=set up, 3=ringing). Returns 200 OK with array of alarm and timer objects.
data.reasoning: Summary is generic. Description is detailed but lacks clarity on response structure and return format. Reorganized to clearly separate alarm vs timer fields, clarified status values, and explicitly stated the return format for better AI agent understanding of response structure.

data.current_description:
This deletes alarms and timers by their id.

`ids` is a list of ids to be deleted. Sending invalid id still returns a 200 OK. The `/` in the ids have to be escaped like `\/`.
data.summary_suggestion: Delete alarms and timers by ID
data.description_suggestion: Deletes one or more alarms or timers by their IDs. Request body must contain `ids` array with the ID(s) to delete. IDs containing forward slashes must be escaped as `\/`. Returns 200 OK even if provided IDs are invalid or non-existent; invalid IDs are silently ignored. Successfully matched IDs are permanently deleted.
data.reasoning: Summary lacks specificity about the ID-based deletion. Description doesn't clearly explain input format, the silent-failure behavior for invalid IDs, or what constitutes success. Added clarity on request structure, escape sequence requirement, and the behavior when IDs don't exist for better AI agent understanding.

Send a POST body with the desired state to enable or disable Do Not Disturb mode. Returns 200 OK with the current or updated Do Not Disturb state. When enabled, the device will suppress notifications and alarms.

data.current_description:
This gets and sets alarms and timers volume.  
**Note:** This is not the same as normal volume.

Volume is a float number in [0, 1] where 0 is minimum and 1 is maximum.  
Sending an empty body gets the volume. Sending `volume` sets the volume.
data.summary_suggestion: Get or set alarm and timer volume
data.description_suggestion: Gets or sets the volume level for alarms and timers independently from device volume. Send an empty POST body to retrieve the current alarm volume setting. Send a POST body with `volume` parameter (float in range [0, 1], where 0 is minimum and 1 is maximum) to set a new alarm volume. Returns 200 OK with the current or updated alarm volume value. Note: This controls alarm/timer volume separately from the device's normal audio volume.
data.reasoning: Summary is too generic. Description lacks clarity on dual GET/SET functionality and response format. Added explicit instructions for both operations, clarified the value range and type, emphasized the separation from normal volume, and specified return format for better AI agent understanding.

Returns the updated or current accessibility configuration.

message: Operation 'GetScanResults' has semantic quality issues: vague_summary, missing_context, missing_output_details. Original summary is too generic. Description lacks context about Part 2 functionality and doesn't explain the relationship to the scan operation. Enhanced summary to specify 'Bluetooth speaker' context and improved description to clarify the scan prerequisite, response structure, and filtering criteria for speaker compatibility.

data.current_description:
*See note for Bluetooth under `/setup/bluetooth/status`*

**For Part 2 only**

This returns a list of all nearby bluetooth devices. While the Home app only shows speakers, this list contains all devices including TVs, mobiles, etc.

`rssi` is signal strength, `name` is name, `mac_address` is mac address.  
`device_class` and `device_type` are bluetooth codes.  

The Home app only lists those devices with `expected_profiles` > 0. Basically, the device should function as a speaker.
data.summary_suggestion: Retrieve nearby Bluetooth speaker scan results
data.description_suggestion: Retrieves a list of all nearby Bluetooth devices detected during a scan (Part 2 functionality). This endpoint returns all discoverable devices including speakers, TVs, and mobile devices. Response includes: `rssi` (signal strength), `name` (device name), `mac_address` (device MAC address), `device_class` and `device_type` (Bluetooth classification codes). Devices with `expected_profiles` > 0 are compatible speakers. Requires an active Bluetooth scan to be initiated via `/setup/bluetooth/scan`.
data.reasoning: Original summary is too generic. Description lacks context about Part 2 functionality and doesn't explain the relationship to the scan operation. Enhanced summary to specify 'Bluetooth speaker' context and improved description to clarify the scan prerequisite, response structure, and filtering criteria for speaker compatibility.

This is to forget paired devices by mac address. Works for both kinds of devices (Part 1 and Part 2).
data.description_suggestion: Removes a paired Bluetooth device from the Google Home device's memory by MAC address. Works for both Part 1 devices (phones/media sources connected to Home) and Part 2 devices (Bluetooth speakers connected to Home). Requires the MAC address of the device to forget in the request body. After removal, the device will need to be re-paired to reconnect. Returns confirmation of successful removal.

message: Operation 'Status' has semantic quality issues: vague_summary, missing_output_details, missing_context. Original summary 'Status' is too generic and doesn't indicate Bluetooth context. Description is verbose with explanatory preamble and contains uncertainty ('Not sure what audio_mode is'). Enhanced summary to specify Bluetooth context and improved description to remove uncertainty, consolidate the Part 1/Part 2 explanation into the main description, clarify all response fields, and provide actionable context for when to use this endpoint.

data.current_description:
> **There are 2 parts of Bluetooth.**
>
> *Part 1*: Devices like phones connect to Home and play audio through Home.  
> For this, /setup/bluetooth/discovery is used to make Home discoverable. Then devices can connect to it as if Home is just another bluetooth speaker.
>
> *Part 2*: Bluetooth speakers connect to Home and Home plays audio through the speakers.
> For this, /setup/bluetooth/scan and /setup/bluetooth/scan_results are used to connect to other speakers.
 >
> The other endpoints are common for both parts.


**For both parts**
 
 This gives the status of all bluetooth things.
- Not sure what `audio_mode` is.
- `discovery_enabled` states whether Home is discoverable. (**Part 1**)
 - `connecting_devices` is a list of all media sources (like phones) connected to Home. (**Part 1**)
- `scanning_enabled` states whether Home scanning for other bluetooth speakers/devices. (**Part 2**)
- `connected_devices` is a list of all speakers connected to Home. (**Part 2**)
data.description_suggestion: Retrieves the complete Bluetooth status of the Google Home device, covering both Part 1 (inbound connections) and Part 2 (outbound connections) functionality. Response includes: `discovery_enabled` (whether Home is discoverable to other devices for Part 1), `connecting_devices` (list of phones/media sources connected to Home for Part 1), `scanning_enabled` (whether Home is scanning for external speakers for Part 2), and `connected_devices` (list of external speakers connected to Home for Part 2). Use this endpoint to determine the current Bluetooth connectivity state before initiating pairing or connection operations.
data.reasoning: Original summary 'Status' is too generic and doesn't indicate Bluetooth context. Description is verbose with explanatory preamble and contains uncertainty ('Not sure what audio_mode is'). Enhanced summary to specify Bluetooth context and improved description to remove uncertainty, consolidate the Part 1/Part 2 explanation into the main description, clarify all response fields, and provide actionable context for when to use this endpoint.
